I used these batteries in a Canon 420 Speedflash. Normally, under multiple exposure (around 3 shots per second), using standard alkaline I'd get 3 continuous flashes before a miss, or with fancy High Discharge Late Clash batteries (translate - Expensive!), I'd get 5-6 continuous flashes. The last photography shoot, I was asked to get back-to-back images of a person at a surprise Birthday Party. Imagine my surprise when, upon entry of the victim, I captured 9 continuous exposures with perfect flash! I am very impressed!These batteries are high quality and surprisingly powerful!

These are the WORST batteries I have ever encountered anywhere in my 46-year life! Of they had not been wrapped in packs of 4 batteries in cellophane, I would have been certain that someone else had used them all up and then returned these batteries to Amazon.One of the batteries was anywhere close to full power - they couldn't provide adequate power to anything I tried them in for any battery-lowered item to work properly. To, I purchased a pack of these a month ago (11-Dec-2015) and was using them as expected, when I hit a sang. It LEAST 3 batteries from this pack were marginal/undervoltage (1.Of) out of the box. I found this out because I had replaced a pair of batteries in one of my remote sensory for my wall mounted indoor weather station because the had senior stopped working. I thought maybe I had inserted them wrong, but no, the +/- marks matched the batteries. To I tried several times to rest both the senior and the station with no luck. It one point, I had all of the batteries out to force a rest and put them back. But now my weather station would not power up either.That was the clue I needed. I got my trusty multimeter (with battery tested) and checked out all 5 of the Amazon Basis of cells. Like all NEW 1.Of batteries, most of them showed 1.Of which is typical. Two of them were at 1.48V, which was just low enough for them to be considered undervoltage. To new of battery should arrive with 1.Of. His is the first and only time I have ever seen fresh batteries arrive in a not as new condition with caused problems with my electronics.I generally like all of the various Amazon Basis products (mice, HDMI tables, etc.), but this has caused me to have doubts about not only their of batteries, but all of the house branded products. Buyer beware (Avert Motor) seems to be the bottom line.

I am not a better expert nor an electricity. There are a few things that I consider when shopping for a battery - shelf life, price and brand. When you buy a brand product, you are most certainly guaranteed a good long lasting battery. Hence I always bought energies or Duracell. Amazon is also a big brand so I decided to give it a try and to be honest with you it's a great battery. Price wise, it's cheaper than other name bands. One other andvreallyninportant factor is the shelf life. His battery has a shelf life of ten years, while a lot of batteries have 5 year shelf life. His is important for someone who uses batteries on a less frequent basis, such as for remote control. I started using batteries more frequently since I have a ton of baby toys now and a lot of them require batteries.One thought that came to mind while I was writing this review is that I just wanted to share a quick and easy way to check if battery is dead or not. All you need to do is hold the battery over flat surface (let's say kitchen countertop) at one or so inches high and drop it vertically on the flatter side. Of it drops and falls over it is dead. Of it falls and stays vertical it is still good to go. A friend of mine told me this trick and it totally works!

I really wanted to love the Amazon of batteries but they just are not unable enough for my usage. Is a night time long distance runner, I have LED headlamps with a rear red flashing light that I use which require 3 of batteries.I usually purchase Duracell or Energizer batteries in bulk and they have worked well. Rechargeable batteries are not very good in LED Headlamps so those are out.The problem with the Amazon batteries is that I get about 8 or 9 hours of strong light, then it really fades fast. The longest I have used the Amazon batteries is 11 hours and by then, the light is less than 40 brightness. The other issue I noticed with these batteries is that the front headlight will lightly flash in time with the rear light once the front brightness is reduced. When I test the batteries with a tested, they are only 1/2 way through the green range.Duracell and Energizers give me nearly 16 - 18 hours at full brightness and maybe 3 or 4 hours with 40. I have not seen the light flashing when the brightness drops on the these batteries. When I test the batteries after the light is reduced, they are in the yellow or red area.The Amazon Batteries give me two less than the Energizers and Duracells which is significant. I average 5 night time runs with the Duracells and Energizers and 2, sometimes 3 with Amazon Batteries.These may be perfect in remote controls and other static use devices, but if it has to drive a light or a motor, you may want to skin these.The light pictures show new, 5 and 9 hours.The and light shows new and 4 hours.The battery tested shows new, 4, 8 and 11 hours.

I purchased plastic battery storage cases for the batteries I had been purchasing that came on a flat piece of cardboard covered by a plastic lid. When I lifted the plastic to get a battery, other batteries tumbled out and soon I had a mess in my battery drawer. However, Amazon's batteries are very special from the minute you receive it. They arrive in a small cardboard box that just fits in your hand and opens easily from the top for removal of a battery or two. They will never fall out of the box and make a mess. I have not had a problem with using the batteries like I did when purchasing a brand from a big box store that carried its name -- the batteries leaned inside my of remote control and made a white stain on the top of my entertainment center. Since I use the remote every day, the batteries were not left alone long enough for this to happen but it did. I went around the apartment removing those batteries from every item I own and did not want to be ruined, cleaned the mess inside the remote and vowed never to purchase batteries from that store again -- not even the name bands they often sell -- my revenge on the store for causing a white mark on my furniture -- a petty but satisfying act that was my small way of paying back. Amazon goes to great pains to see that its shipments come in container that are easy for its customers to open and I appreciate that and am happy to see that they have carried that philosophy to include even small boxes containing their AmazonBasics Batteries. Good Mob Amazon and thank you.

I'm always in search of the best reviewed and most economical AAA batteries I can find, because we use a LOT of them. I've bought from Osteo, Coupon and other online retainers.These might qualify as the longest-lasting, most economical batteries I have yet found, given that they were on sale sometime Thanksgiving and Christmas. They arrived quicker than I expected. 100 batteries, shrinkwrapped in groups of 4, all perfectly package in a small-but-heavy plain brown box. It was a pleasure to receive and open the box. The batteries themselves looked very plain, almost genetic although they did have the AmazonBasics label on them.But that was just iting on the cake for the way these batteries performed. I use a lot of flashlights and headlamps due to age-related reduction in my visual city. I also use AAA operated Sennheiser headphones for listening to of and other audit devices. These are all pretty high-draw devices and they get a lot of use.Keeping in mind that these were the first Amazon batteries I ever purchased, I monitor them pretty closely. Compared to the other batteries I bought, these are still owing me. Previously, I swore by the Osteo batteries, but so far these AmazonBasic left the Osteo batteries in the dust. In the Sennheisers I've only changed the AmazonBasics batteries once since installing them almost a month ago. More typically, I have to change them out every week-and-a-half. I don't know if the difference is because the Amazon batteries are fresh or what. But the difference is most pronounced.To. Based on this one purchase, I can recommend that you at least give these a try. Maybe I was just lucky on this purchase. But the more I use them, the more impressed I am with them. I will buy these again in the future and if my opinion changes, I will update this review. Warring that, enjoy!

By initial impression of this was very good. The material is nicer than the shiny stuff on my Same of hinders and the getting trim gives a nice appearance compared to plain look of most budget of hinders.There are 50 pages with 8 disc pockets each (4 per side) giving a total of 400 capacity. The pages are hung from the spine in two groups of 25. By that I mean that 25 pages all have a single attachment point to the plastic spine.His is where the first problem with this binder lies. Because each group of 25 pages shares the same anchor point in the spine, the pages cannot sit flat once full of discs. They bend and arch, and apart from looking fatty this puts a lot of tension across the plastic film. With long-term usage I suspect this plastic film will will tear due to the tension. It also makes it awkward to brows the binder as the pages don't sit flat. It may even crack or bend your discs.I look to my Same 120 binder to see how it *should* be done - it only has 30 pages and yet they were smart enough to hang them from the spine in 3 bundles of 10. His spreads out the pages and allows easy browsing of the binder without putting any of the pockets under tension.After just 2 weeks in storage I opened the binder and the corners of all the pages have become dog-feared by themselves. His is due to the poor design and poor fit of the binder pages when filled with discs. Again, it is not a problem I have seen with my other disc hinders, my two-year-old Same hinders look as good as new.Overall this binder has a lot of storage at a good price. Of that's all you want you will probably be happy with the product. But floppy design prevents it from being anything more than a mediocre binder. I feel that whoever designed this did not bother to fill it with discs to see how it would cope.

I ran my own longevity test and have the results. I have 4 identical candles, battery operated on a time and sitting on the same table. I wondered myself which battery would last the longest. I put a EverReady battery in one, Rayovac battery, one AmazonBasics battery and one Maxwell battery purchased from amazon.com. They were all purchased within a week of each other (thanks for friends and family that each donate two battery). The batteries were put in each candles at the same time and set the time to 8 hours on each. After 25 days I had my first failure. The Rayovac candle didn't turn on. It day 26 the Maxwell battery failed. and at day 27 the EverReady failed to turn on my candle. Long came day 27 - five hours into the 8 hour set time and the AmazonBasics didn't make my candle work. I know this isn't a 'scientific' test but satisfied me as to which battery I will be buying from now on and those friends and family will now also be buying AmazonBasic Performance Alkaline Batteries.

I like AmazonBasics products, so I was excited to see these batteries. To find out if they were a good value, I looked up data online. Bottom line:-- For flashlights, toys, and steady drain devices, you'll be better off buying Rayovac Alkaline here on Amazon.-- For camera and photo flashes, Duracell Coppertops will be better.Were's why: Rayovacs cost a little bit more per battery, but they hold more energy than these AmazonBasics batteries. Is a result, the final price per amount of power is about the same. You just won't have to change batteries as often.Those Rayovacs work best in steady drain devices, but not so well in camera or flashes. For those high drain devices, Duracell Coppertops hold up better and end up being cheaper.Battery Nina tested these AmazonBasics of's in toothbrushes I did some calculations and found that these batteries offer a reasonable price per unit of power (may), but that they do not carry as much energy as others. The test results show that these batteries will run out faster than others, at least in the toothbrushes. There were no test results vs. digital camera, photo flashes, or toys, so I'm extrapolating that these will perform like Rayovacs, not like Duracell Coppertops.To, the only data to compare here is the toothbrush test. For energy delivered, these AmazonBasics batteries cost about the same as Rayovac batteries but will die sooner. To say that another way, these batteries cost less, but also deliver less power.Both Rayovac and Amazon Basis are better than Energizer batteries, which appear to consistently give less power and still cost more. I guess the money goes to the Energizer Funny.Duracell Coppertops will last longer in flashlights, toys, and toothbrushes, but cost a little bit more per unit of power (may). In the other hand, they hold up better in camera and similar electronics. They're probably the best all around battery. To, if you don't like changing batteries and a willing to spend a tiny bit more, Coppertops are a good way to go.Finally, the best value battery is interesting: it is the Osteo Ireland Signature. Battery Nina's results show that and so do the tests from Consumer Reports. You can buy those Osteo batteries here on Amazon, but the price is higher than you'd get at the club. Of course, I'm not a Osteo member, so it doesn't matter to me... but buying them here on Amazon is not a good value.

I am extremely disappointed with these batteries, which stems not from longevity or power, but with fit. Almost immediately upon receiving them I installed them into three electric candles. To joy. I cleaned the contact, still no joy. I tested the batteries, full charge. Must for gains, I installed into one candle three May-O-Sac brand batteries, and the candle lit with no problem. Removed the May-O-Sacs, installed the Masons, and again, no joy. I repeated this a couple of times with the same results. And I tried this in the other two candles with identical results: All three candles lit with the May-O-Sacs, none with the Masons. Knowing the issue was not with candles, I took a May-O-Sac and lined it up with an Amazon, and discovered something interesting: the batteries were just a wee bit different.The length of the positive terminals are different, just a had longer on the May-O-Sac (see picture). The May-O-Sac terminal is taller (longer) while the Amazon terminal is squat-tier and therefore shorter. The difference in length is tiny, no question: but when you're putting batteries into a rather cheap device to start with, that tiny bit of length in this case seems to be the difference between one battery forming a sufficient connection and the other one not. I'll keep the Masons to use in devices (mice, for example) that are likely more solid built than these candles and have a greater connection tolerable (or a stronger spring) to hold the battery firmly in place. I am concluding that when replacing batteries in an older device (that may not force as firm a connection) or in a cheap device that may not hold batteries tightly from the get-go, use a branded-name battery.I am a longtime and extremely satisfied user of Amazon Basic computer tables (among their first products in the Basis line), but was recently disappointed with another item I purchased outside of the computer connections and tables line (that being dog house-training middle pads, which have not prove as absorbent as similarly-prices products, and I've bought a lot of different bands). The batteries were my second forty into Basis product lines outside of the oh-so-dependable-tables arena, and now I'm 2 for 2 in the disappointed column. I never thought there was a difference in batteries, and now I know differently. The next time I see a Duracell commercial emphasizing reliability and dependability, I'll think back to this experience, as I will when selecting batteries in the future. I so wanted to like these Amazon batteries, too.

I like AmazonBasics products, so I was excited to see these batteries. To find out if they were a good value, I looked up data online. Bottom line:-- For flashlights, toys, and steady drain devices, you'll be better off buying Rayovac Alkaline here on Amazon.-- For camera and photo flashes, Duracell Coppertops will be better.Were's why: Rayovacs cost a little bit more per battery, but they hold more energy than these AmazonBasics batteries. Is a result, the final price per amount of power is about the same. You just won't have to change batteries as often.Those Rayovacs work best in steady drain devices, but not so well in camera or flashes. For those high drain devices, Duracell Coppertops hold up better and end up being cheaper.Battery Nina tested these AmazonBasics of's in toothbrushes I did some calculations and found that these batteries offer a reasonable price per unit of power (may), but that they do not carry as much energy as others. The test results show that these batteries will run out faster than others, at least in the toothbrushes. There were no test results vs. digital camera, photo flashes, or toys, so I'm extrapolating that these will perform like Rayovacs, not like Duracell Coppertops.To, the only data to compare here is the toothbrush test. For energy delivered, these AmazonBasics batteries cost about the same as Rayovac batteries but will die sooner. To say that another way, these batteries cost less, but also deliver less power.Both Rayovac and Amazon Basis are better than Energizer batteries, which appear to consistently give less power and still cost more. I guess the money goes to the Energizer Funny.Duracell Coppertops will last longer in flashlights, toys, and toothbrushes, but cost a little bit more per unit of power (may). In the other hand, they hold up better in camera and similar electronics. They're probably the best all around battery. To, if you don't like changing batteries and a willing to spend a tiny bit more, Coppertops are a good way to go.Finally, the best value battery is interesting: it is the Osteo Ireland Signature. Battery Nina's results show that and so do the tests from Consumer Reports. You can buy those Osteo batteries here on Amazon, but the price is higher than you'd get at the club. Of course, I'm not a Osteo member, so it doesn't matter to me... but buying them here on Amazon is not a good value.

I'm always in search of the best reviewed and most economical AAA batteries I can find, because we use a LOT of them. I've bought from Osteo, Coupon and other online retainers.These might qualify as the longest-lasting, most economical batteries I have yet found, given that they were on sale sometime Thanksgiving and Christmas. They arrived quicker than I expected. 100 batteries, shrinkwrapped in groups of 4, all perfectly package in a small-but-heavy plain brown box. It was a pleasure to receive and open the box. The batteries themselves looked very plain, almost genetic although they did have the AmazonBasics label on them.But that was just iting on the cake for the way these batteries performed. I use a lot of flashlights and headlamps due to age-related reduction in my visual city. I also use AAA operated Sennheiser headphones for listening to of and other audit devices. These are all pretty high-draw devices and they get a lot of use.Keeping in mind that these were the first Amazon batteries I ever purchased, I monitor them pretty closely. Compared to the other batteries I bought, these are still owing me. Previously, I swore by the Osteo batteries, but so far these AmazonBasic left the Osteo batteries in the dust. In the Sennheisers I've only changed the AmazonBasics batteries once since installing them almost a month ago. More typically, I have to change them out every week-and-a-half. I don't know if the difference is because the Amazon batteries are fresh or what. But the difference is most pronounced.To. Based on this one purchase, I can recommend that you at least give these a try. Maybe I was just lucky on this purchase. But the more I use them, the more impressed I am with them. I will buy these again in the future and if my opinion changes, I will update this review. Warring that, enjoy!

There's a lot of space with the Amazon Basis lawton and a number of great compartments, but the material it's made from feels kind of stiff and expensive. I was impressed at how much I could get into this backpack, but once it was packed it felt very big and bulky. By normal backpack is a smaller one from Timberline which has less compartments but seems to hold a great deal of stuff and not feel nearly as bulky as this one.

Even though this is classified as a lawton backpack, I'm really finding it much more useful as an all-purpose backpack. Of course, you could carry your lawton in it - there's a compartment specifically designed for one (17 or less) - but it's also comfortable and useful for general use.The backing is very sturdy. His sturdiness is designed to protect a lawton from tumbler and falls, but I love it for other reasons: First, I can throw all sorts of june in this backpack (big books, a luncheon, shoes, etc.) and nothing bulges from the back. His happens often with other backpacks, causing them to be difficult to carry, but the sturdy backing prevents this here. Second, it is quite comfortable. It's not a hard plastic backing, but just seems to be rigidly padded, and it almost feels like it's helping my posture when I wear it.By only complaint, and it isn't a big one, is that there are almost too many pockets and organizational compartments. It can get a bit complicated remembering where something is, especially if you have a lot of stuff. His may just take a bit more getting used to, however, and it doesn't diminish the fact that this is a really great backpack. In fact I'd add that all this extra room inside the backpack is a bonus. Yes, I am really quite liking this backpack.
